contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox person |image = Dramatenselevskola1922.jpg |imagesize = | caption = Drama elevskola 1922, from left to right [[Lena Cederqvist]], [[Karl-Magnus Thulstrup]], [[Mona Martensson]], [[Mimi Pollak]], [[Vera Schmiterlöw]], [[Greta Garbo]], '''Alf Sjöberg''' and [[Håkan Westergren]] | name = Alf Sjöberg | birth_date = {{birth date|1903|6|21|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | death_date = {{death date and age|1980|4|17|1903|6|21|df=y}} | death_place = Stockholm, Sweden | othername = | occupation = Film director | yearsactive = 1925–1969 }} '''Sven Erik Alf Sjöberg''' (21 June 1903, [[Stockholm]] – 17 April 1980) was a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[theatre director|theatre]] and [[film director]]. He won the [[Palme d'Or|Grand Prix du Festival]] at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] twice: in 1946 for ''[[Iris and the Lieutenant]]'' ({{lang-sv|Iris och löjtnantshjärta}}) (part of an eleven-way tie), and in 1951 for his film ''[[Miss Julie (1951 film)|Miss Julie]]'' ({{lang-sv|Fröken Julie}})<ref name="Cannes">{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/artist/id/13267.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Alf Sjöberg |accessdate=2011-05-15|work=festival-cannes.com}}</ref> (an adaption of the [[August Strindberg]]'s play which tied with [[Vittorio De Sica]]'s ''[[Miracle in Milan]]''). Despite his success with films ''[[Torment (1944 film)|Torment]]'' (1944) and ''[[Miss Julie (1951 film)|Miss Julie]]'', Sjöberg was above all, and foremost, a stage director; perhaps the greatest at [[Dramaten]] (alongside first [[Olof Molander]] and later [[Ingmar Bergman]]). He was a First Director of Sweden's [[Royal Dramatic Theatre]] in the years 1930–1980, where he staged a large number of remarkable and historic productions. Sjöberg was also a pioneer director for early Swedish TV theatre (his 1955 TV theatre production of ''[[Hamlet]]'' is a national milestone). Sjöberg died in a car accident on his way to rehearsal at the [[Royal Dramatic Theatre]] in Stockholm. ==Filmography== ===Actor=== *''The Ingmar Inheritance'' (''Ingemarsarvet'') (1925) *''Ådalens poesi'' (1928) *''Resan Bort'' (1945) ===Director=== *''[[Den starkaste]]'' (1929) *''[[They Staked Their Lives]]'' (''Med livet som insats'') (1940) *''[[Den blomstertid]]'' (1940) *''[[Hem från Babylon]]'' (1941) *''[[The Heavenly Play]]'' (''Himlaspelet'') (1942) *''[[Kungajakt]]'' (1944) *''[[Torment (1944 film)|Torment]]'' (''Hets'') (1944) From a synopsis by [[Ingmar Bergman]], who served as assistant director. Nominated for the Golden Lion at the Venice Film Festival in 1947. *''[[Resan bort]]'' (1945) *''[[Iris and the Lieutenant]]'' (''Iris och löjtnantshjärta'') (1946) Shared the Grand Prix du Festival International du Film at the [[1946 Cannes Film Festival]] *''[[Only a Mother]]'' (''Bara en mor'') (1949) *''[[Miss Julie (1951 film)|Miss Julie]]'' (''Fröken Julie'') (1951) Shared the Grand Prix du Festival International du Film at the [[1951 Cannes Film Festival]] *''[[Barabbas (1953 film)|Barabbas]]'' (1953) *''[[Karin Månsdotter (film)|Karin Månsdotter]]'' (1954) *''[[Wild Birds]]'' (''Vildfåglar'') (1955) *''[[Last Pair Out]]'' (''Sista paret ut'') (1956) *''[[The Judge (film)|The Judge]]'' (''Domaren'') (1960) *''[[Ön]]'' (1966) *''The Father'' (''Fadern'') (1969) ===Writer=== *''They Staked Their Lives'' (''Med livet som insats'') (1940) *''Den blomstertid'' (1940) *''Hem från Babylon'' (1941) *''Only a Mother'' (''Bara en mor'') (1949) *''The Heavenly Play'' (''Himlaspelet'') (1942) *''Resan bort'' (1945) *''Miss Julie'' (''Fröken Julie'') (1951) *''Karin Månsdotter'' (1954) *''Wild Birds'' (''Vildfåglar'') (1955) *''The Judge'' (''Domaren'') (1960) *''Ön'' (1966) ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb name|0803549}} *{{sfdb|59143}} {{Authority control|VIAF=47025050}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME =Sjoberg, Alf | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Swedish film director | DATE OF BIRTH = 21 June 1903 | PLACE OF BIRTH = [[Stockholm]], [[Sweden]] | DATE OF DEATH = 17 April 1980 | PLACE OF DEATH = Stockholm, Sweden }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Sjoberg, Alf}} [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1980 deaths]] [[Category:People from Stockholm]] [[Category:Road accident deaths in Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish theatre directors]] [[Category:Swedish film directors]] [[Category:Best Director Guldbagge Award winners]] {{Sweden-film-director-stub}}
